original_note:
Patient: John Smith, 58-year-old male
Medical Record #: 1234
Arrived for a follow-up appointment complaining of ongoing fatigue and occasional blurred vision. Denies chest pain.

Known history of Type 2 Diabetes (T2D), currently on Metformin 500 mg BID and occasional insulin injections. Previous lab work indicated an elevated A1C of 8.7%. The patient also mentioned that his cat, Fluffy, seems lethargic lately. The overhead fluorescent lights in the waiting area were flickering, making it difficult to read the nurse's quick notes.

He reports mild numbness in his feet, suggesting early peripheral neuropathy. Other comorbidity includes hypertension, managed with Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Nurse Linda noted that he had tested negative for COVID-19 last month.

Next step: schedule a fasting glucose test in two weeks to reassess. Consider adjusting insulin dosage if glucose remains high. Also, the patient could not recall if he still smokes occasionally. Overall plan is to reinforce medication adherence and review dietary habits at the next visit.

extracted_fields.reason for visit: follow-up appointment complaining of ongoing fatigue and occasional blurred vision
extracted_fields.next steps: schedule a fasting glucose test in two weeks to reassess. Consider adjusting insulin dosage if glucose remains high. Also, the patient could not recall if he still smokes occasionally. Overall plan is to reinforce medication adherence and review dietary habits at the next visit.

original_note:
Patient: Linda Green, 45-year-old female
Medical Record #: 5678
Chief Complaint: Persistent headaches and tingling in left foot.

Past medical history includes Type 2 Diabetes, diagnosed three years ago. Current medications: Metformin 500 mg BID, Atorvastatin 10 mg daily. Last recorded A1C was 7.9%. Reports occasional insomnia, which she attributes to stress at her job as a florist. 
She mentioned her laptop battery died right before the telehealth visit, which caused a delay in connection. Reports that she recently started a home yoga routine recommended by her sister.

Plan: Continue current medication regimen, order routine labs for lipids and A1C. Advise patient to monitor glucose levels more frequently if headaches persist.

extracted_fields.reason for visit: Persistent headaches and tingling in left foot
extracted_fields.next steps: Continue current medication regimen, order routine labs for lipids and A1C. Advise patient to monitor glucose levels more frequently if headaches persist

original_note:
Patient: Michael Brown, 62-year-old male
Medical Record #: 9102
Follow-up for hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes. Patient arrived wearing a cast on his right arm (unrelated to current condition; he slipped on ice last week).

Vital signs: BP 150/95, pulse 78, temp 98.6°F. On Metformin 1000 mg daily, Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Last known A1C was 8.1%. He also takes a multivitamin but couldn’t recall the brand. 
He mentioned watching the hospital cafeteria menu “go digital” recently, which distracted him from asking the nurse some questions.

Next step: Increase Lisinopril dose if BP remains elevated. Schedule blood tests to check renal function. Advise patient to keep arm elevated and follow up with orthopedics.

extracted_fields.reason for visit: Follow-up for hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes
extracted_fields.next steps: Increase Lisinopril dose if BP remains elevated. Schedule blood tests to check renal function. Advise patient to keep arm elevated and follow up with orthopedics.

original_note:
Patient: Sarah Johnson, 50-year-old female
Medical Record #: 3344
Complaint: Frequent urination, increased thirst. States she has been feeling anxious at night.

Diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes last year. Current regimen: Glipizide 5 mg daily, occasionally forgets her dose. Vitals: BP 140/88, HR 82. She’s also being treated for hyperlipidemia with Simvastatin 20 mg daily. Lab results from last month show A1C of 7.6%. She brought up her hobby of painting landscapes, stating it helps her relax. 

Plan: Reinforce medication adherence. Consider switching to Metformin if blood glucose remains high. Schedule follow-up in 4 weeks to reassess symptoms.

extracted_fields.reason for visit: Frequent urination, increased thirst. States she has been feeling anxious at night.
extracted_fields.next steps: Reinforce medication adherence. Consider switching to Metformin if blood glucose remains high. Schedule follow-up in 4 weeks to reassess symptoms.

original_note:
Patient: Carlos Ramirez, 55-year-old male
Medical Record #: 2211
Presenting with ongoing fatigue and left knee pain. The knee issue may be orthopedic in nature due to a past sports injury.

Known history of Type 2 Diabetes, on Metformin 500 mg BID and Jardiance 10 mg daily. Last known A1C was 9.2%. He complains about his neighbor’s noisy parrot, which has disrupted his sleep. Currently also on Losartan 50 mg daily for hypertension. 
Nurse notes that the patient declined the flu shot, stating personal preference.

Assessment & Plan: Increase Jardiance dosage if next labs still indicate poor glucose control. Recommend an orthopedic consult for knee pain. Counsel patient on sleep hygiene.

original_note:
Patient: Rebecca Lee, 29-year-old female
Medical Record #: 7788
Chief Complaint: Rapid weight gain over the past month. Denies any significant dietary changes.

Newly diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes, started on Metformin 500 mg daily last week. Family history: mother with thyroid disorder. She also mentioned her fiancé is an avid cyclist, and they plan to ride together next month. Vitals: BP 128/80, HR 70, no fever. 
Early lab work: A1C at 8.0%. Reports feeling frustrated about constantly having to check blood sugar. She also has mild seasonal allergies, taking OTC antihistamines occasionally.

Plan: Encourage diet and exercise modifications. Schedule comprehensive labs, including thyroid function tests, to rule out other causes of weight gain.

extracted_fields.reason for visit: Rapid weight gain over the past month. Denies any significant dietary changes.
extracted_fields.next steps: Encourage diet and exercise modifications. Schedule comprehensive labs, including thyroid function tests, to rule out other causes of weight gain.

original_note:
Patient: Thomas Wilson, 67-year-old male
Medical Record #: 9890
Follow-up for chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage 3 and Type 2 Diabetes. The patient mentioned that his granddaughter’s birthday party is tomorrow, and he’s anxious about the buffet options.

Medications: Metformin 500 mg BID, Insulin glargine (10 units nightly), and Amlodipine 5 mg daily. Last labs show A1C of 8.5%, eGFR 45 mL/min/1.73m². Patient mentions mild fatigue but denies any chest pain. 
He also complained about the waiting room television being too loud. Advised him on the importance of dietary potassium restriction due to CKD.

Plan: Monitor renal function closely. Possibly consult nephrology if eGFR declines further. Recommend dietician referral to manage both CKD and T2D.

extracted_fields.reason for visit: Follow-up for chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage 3 and Type 2 Diabetes
extracted_fields.next steps: Monitor renal function closely. Possibly consult nephrology if eGFR declines further. Recommend dietician referral to manage both CKD and T2D.

original_note:
Patient: Emily Dawson, 36-year-old female
Medical Record #: 5566
Complaint: Increased thirst and frequent urination for the past two weeks. Reports she recently started a stressful new job at a tech startup.

Diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes four years ago, not always compliant with medication. Prescribed Metformin 500 mg once daily, but she admits she sometimes forgets. A1C from last visit was 9.0%. She says her dog has been ill, which also caused her to miss some doses. 
Currently experiencing mild anxiety, considering counseling. She also notes she’s been skipping breakfast to get to work earlier.

Plan: Stress the importance of medication adherence. Consider adding a short-acting insulin if glucose remains uncontrolled. Advise adopting consistent meal times.

extracted_fields.reason for visit: Increased thirst and frequent urination for the past two weeks. Reports she recently started a stressful new job at a tech startup.
extracted_fields.next steps: Stress the importance of medication adherence. Consider adding a short-acting insulin if glucose remains uncontrolled. Advise adopting consistent meal times.

original_note:
Patient: Robert Kim, 48-year-old male
Medical Record #: 3030
Annual exam visit. History of Type 2 Diabetes and hyperlipidemia. Doesn’t recall the last time he did a comprehensive lab workup.

Medications: Metformin 1000 mg BID, Rosuvastatin 10 mg daily. Vitals: BP 140/90, HR 76, no fever. He brought his daughter along, who was playing a video game loudly in the exam room. Mentions occasional blurry vision at night. 
He also says he’s tried a new “herbal tea” for general wellness but isn’t sure if it interacts with his prescriptions.

Plan: Order full blood panel including fasting glucose and lipid profile. Encourage the patient to maintain an updated medication list, including supplements.

extracted_fields.reason for visit: Annual exam visit
extracted_fields.next steps: Order full blood panel including fasting glucose and lipid profile. Encourage the patient to maintain an updated medication list, including supplements.

original_note:
Patient: Diane Carter, 60-year-old female
Medical Record #: 1212
Scheduled for routine diabetes check. States she has been feeling increasingly tired, especially after lunch. Also complains about an annoying humming sound from the exam room’s ventilation system.

Past medical history: Type 2 Diabetes (15 years), mild depression (on Sertraline 50 mg daily). Current diabetes regimen: Insulin detemir 15 units twice daily, Metformin 500 mg BID. Last measured A1C was 8.4%. She takes a daily walk around the neighborhood but hasn’t done so this week due to bad weather. 
She noted her neighbor recommends a supplement that promises to “stabilize blood sugar,” but she’s unsure about it.

Assessment & Plan: Consider adjusting insulin dose if postprandial spikes continue. Advise patient to consult her pharmacist before trying new supplements. Reinforce mental health follow-up.

extracted_fields.reason for visit: routine diabetes check
next steps: Consider adjusting insulin dose if postprandial spikes continue
Advise patient to consult her pharmacist before trying new supplements
Reinforce mental health follow-up

original_note:
Patient: Lisa Chang, 72-year-old female
Medical Record #: 4545
Chief Complaint: Increased fatigue, mild swelling in ankles.

Past medical history: Type 2 Diabetes for 10 years, hypertension, mild osteoarthritis. Medications include Metformin 1000 mg BID, Lisinopril 20 mg daily, and occasional acetaminophen for joint pain. Last A1C recorded at 8.3%.
She mentioned that her neighbor’s car alarm went off at 2 AM last night, disturbing her sleep. She also wonders if her new herbal tea could interact with her diabetes meds.

Plan: Check renal function, evaluate for possible edema related to hypertension. Advise patient to continue blood sugar monitoring and bring the herbal tea label next visit.

extracted_fields.next steps: Check renal function, evaluate for possible edema related to hypertension. Advise patient to continue blood sugar monitoring and bring the herbal tea label next visit

original_note:
Patient: George Patterson, 55-year-old male
Medical Record #: 7676
Complaint: Ongoing blurred vision and numbness in fingertips.

He has a 5-year history of Type 2 Diabetes, currently on Metformin 500 mg BID and Glipizide 5 mg daily. Last known A1C was 9.1%. The patient said he was in a hurry because he needs to pick up his daughter from basketball practice.
Also notes sporadic ringing in his ears, which he attributes to loud construction near his home. Reports occasional noncompliance with diet due to frequent travel for work.

Assessment & Plan: Increase Glipizide dosage if readings remain high. Recommend ophthalmology consult for blurred vision. Stress dietary adjustments and consistent medication schedule.

Patient: Maria Ortega, 63-year-old female
Medical Record #: 3022
Chief Complaint: Frequent urination, increased thirst over the last month.

Type 2 Diabetes diagnosed 4 years ago, managed with Metformin 1000 mg BID and Sitagliptin 100 mg daily. Last lab results: A1C = 8.7%, mild anemia noted. The patient mentioned watching a TV news segment on new diabetes treatments and is curious about injectable medications. 
She also mentioned that her cat knocked over her pill organizer, and she’s worried she may have missed some doses.

Plan: Recheck blood counts, consider adding basal insulin if next labs remain uncontrolled. Reinforce medication adherence and proper pill organization.

Patient: Anthony Reynolds, 48-year-old male
Medical Record #: 8833
Follow-up visit for Type 2 Diabetes. Reports intermittent chest tightness, but denies severe pain.

Current regimen: Metformin 500 mg TID, Atorvastatin 20 mg daily for hyperlipidemia. He notes that the waiting room was too cold, causing discomfort. Last known A1C: 7.8%. He’s also been dealing with a recent job change, which he says contributes to stress eating.
Vitals: BP 145/92, HR 80, Temp 98.2°F.

Next step: Rule out cardiac causes of chest tightness. Continue current therapy for diabetes. Suggest stress management techniques and dietary counseling.

Patient: Priya Kapoor, 34-year-old female
Medical Record #: 1122
Chief Complaint: Sudden weight loss, fatigue, and occasional dizziness.

Newly diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes, started on Metformin 500 mg BID last week. She mentions her upcoming vacation to Hawaii, worried about managing her diet there. Also complains that her phone battery kept dying, preventing her from tracking glucose in an app.
Labs: A1C = 9.4%, slightly elevated liver enzymes. She denies alcohol use.

Plan: Investigate liver enzyme elevation, reinforce dietary recommendations, ensure patient understands how to monitor glucose while traveling. Schedule follow-up labs in 6 weeks.

Patient: James Henderson, 59-year-old male
Medical Record #: 3339
Routine check-up for Type 2 Diabetes and hyperlipidemia. Patient states he has minimal exercise since winter started.

Medications: Metformin 1000 mg BID, Rosuvastatin 10 mg daily. Last A1C was 7.5%. He mentions a new hobby, amateur radio, which keeps him seated for prolonged periods. He forgot to wear his glasses today, making it hard to read the consent forms.
Plan: Encourage more physical activity, potentially indoors. Order new labs to monitor lipid profile and blood glucose control. Discuss possible addition of medication for better glycemic management if needed.

Patient: Anna Li, 27-year-old female
Medical Record #: 5050
Complaint: Headaches, frequent nausea, and feeling jittery at work.

She has a 2-year history of Type 2 Diabetes, controlled on Metformin 500 mg daily. Last recorded A1C was 8.2%. She started drinking high-caffeine energy drinks to cope with long shifts as a nurse. Admits possible dehydration. Also notes that the overhead speaker announcements are too loud in her hospital unit, causing added stress.

Plan: Advise limiting high-caffeine beverages. Re-check fasting glucose. Consider adjusting medication if glucose remains elevated. Suggest hydration and headache evaluation if symptoms persist.

original_note:
Patient: Kevin Wright, 66-year-old male
Medical Record #: 9292
Follow-up for Type 2 Diabetes and chronic back pain. States the pain worsens when he sits in his recliner too long.

Current meds: Metformin 500 mg TID, Ibuprofen PRN for back pain, and Lisinopril 10 mg daily for mild hypertension. Last A1C: 8.9%. He’s annoyed that the pharmacy recently changed his pill bottle labels, making them harder to read. 
Complains of slight dizziness upon standing, possibly orthostatic. He also mentions he’s been skipping breakfast, which might contribute to blood sugar swings.

Assessment & Plan: Evaluate orthostatic hypotension. Increase dietary supervision, possibly add short-acting insulin if glycemic control remains inadequate. Suggest physical therapy referral for back pain.

extracted_fields.reason for visit: Follow-up for Type 2 Diabetes and chronic back pain
medications: Lisinopril 10 mg daily for mild hypertension
extracted_fields.next steps: Evaluate orthostatic hypotension. Increase dietary supervision, possibly add short-acting insulin if glycemic control remains inadequate. Suggest physical therapy referral for back pain.

Patient: Olivia Baker, 43-year-old female
Medical Record #: 7070
Chief Complaint: Persistent fatigue, difficulty concentrating at work.

Type 2 Diabetes for 5 years, managed with Metformin 1000 mg BID and Empagliflozin 10 mg daily. Last A1C was 8.1%. She commented on the clinic’s new self-check-in kiosks, saying the interface was confusing. She also notes that her child’s soccer schedule is interfering with her meal planning.

Plan: Reassess medication dosage, possibly increase Empagliflozin. Encourage more consistent meal times. Schedule an A1C test in 3 weeks to monitor any improvement.

original_note:
Patient: David Kim, 70-year-old male
Medical Record #: 6262
Presentation: Mild shortness of breath when climbing stairs, random spikes in blood glucose.

Past medical history: Type 2 Diabetes (15 years), CHF (congestive heart failure), and chronic bronchitis. Current regimen includes Metformin 500 mg BID, Furosemide 20 mg daily, and carvedilol 6.25 mg BID. Last known A1C was 9.0%. 
He mentioned that he accidentally gave his dog the wrong brand of dog food this morning, which caused some confusion in his routine. Also complains about a drafty window in his bedroom disturbing his sleep.

Plan: Evaluate cardiac status, check BNP levels. Consider adding insulin if glucose remains poorly controlled. Recommend addressing sleep quality issues and ensuring a consistent medication schedule.

check BNP levels
